Historical use:
When a paper is referred to over a number of decades and becomes almost colloquial. A paper's reproducibility may only have been tested once (if at all!) and yet may be treated as truth. Innovative papers from decades ago that continue to be name-dropped should still be held to same standards of reproducibility as new papers where possible. We as a community can't give these seminal papers a 'free ride'. 

Poor quality online material:
Some articles are reproduced from scans, especially if older or produced in print originally. The figures are often distorted or the colours affected. This affects whether the results can be reproduced. This may not be a pervasive problem but could have an affect. This ties into the following point. 

Reliance on conference abstracts references: 
Conference abstracts are excellent for innovation. However, some individuals use this as a loop-hole. An individual may refer to a conference abstract which may not be available or only partially available e.g. the conference abstract but not the associated poster/slides.  I believe any research should be treated with care (regardless of its source) and the reader should have access to the data required to make an informed decision. Conference abstracts, at least in my experience, fall into this category a lot more than other research outputs.

Method:
If you use the same mathematical function 100 times you *could* get the same result BUT the method may not be valid/appropriate. The link between validity and reproducibility is difficult.

I sometimes need to provide a one-off workflow to a research student or collaborator, based on one I have devised previously and published on.  Usually, my first step is to get my previous code working and assemble the dataset I used.  This isn't usually very difficult, so long as the build process is clear and the data in the study are still available.  (They may not be for commercial reasons, say, but my data is generally open access after some time.)  The key is to document any steps in clear documentation or code where they were not made explicit in publications.  This is best done by including a single script which does the entire analysis on the data at hand and makes the figures and tables.  This is often not possible with large datasets, in which case a pseudo-script can be written where the large-data or -compute parts are labelled as such and pointers are left to the scripts and data elsewhere (e.g., on HPC machines).  In this case, it's important to have local copies of those scripts, but as I'm a bit paranoid about data loss, this is part of my routine in any case.

I may be atypical, but doing something like this is what I try to drill in to my students.  A lab book can be very useful too (and I pretty much insist on them), but frequently it takes too long for another person to follow a notebookâ€”say if someone quickly leaves for another careerâ€”for them to be useful.

column45:
There are three major issues in my opinion: 

(1) Lack of publicly available raw data. Many 2D and 3D seismic volumes exist but are impossible to access for academic researchers, unless they directly have a collaborative agreement. It would be great if petroleum and seismic acquisition companies were more open to sharing data with academic researchers.
(2) Lack of published processed data. Almost all articles published with seismic data just point to a repository where there is raw data. However, others may not have the same software and access to algorithms to reproduce the processed images. It should be mandatory to upload SEGY-Y files of the images used in any published journal article. This would give researchers a chance to build on the interpretation of others without needed processing skills and software (not to mention that processing a seismic volume can take several years, and Masters/PhD students won't have time for that). 
(3) Lack of published interpretations. Would be nice to have published seismic horizons and faults that are published in journals. This one is a little more tricky. In my last manuscript, I did all of the interpretations in Adobe Illustrator, so I would be happy to upload .ai files with the interpretations, but I wouldn't be able to provide x,y,z grids, for example.
